article.title: HI absorption in nearby compact radio galaxies

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows the spectral indices between 20 GHz and lower frequencies (8.4/4.8 GHz) for 49 compact radio galaxies. What type of spectral index do the majority of these sources exhibit?
This figure compares the 21-cm line strength with the measured flux density of compact radio sources. What trend is observed regarding the detection of HI absorption in relation to the flux density?
choices: HI absorption is preferentially detected towards weaker sources.
There is no correlation between HI absorption detection and flux density.
HI absorption is preferentially detected towards stronger sources.
HI absorption is only detected towards sources with flux densities above a certain threshold.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure presents a WISE color-color diagram comparing W1-W2 with W2-W3 bands for two samples of radio galaxies.  What do the different colors (red and blue) represent?
choices: Red represents high-excitation radio galaxies (HERGs) and blue represents low-excitation radio galaxies (LERGs).
Red represents sources with detected HI absorption and blue represents sources without detected HI absorption.
Red represents compact radio sources and blue represents extended radio sources.
Red represents sources with high star formation rates and blue represents sources with low star formation rates.

multiple_choice_question.text: This formula describes the relationship between the column density of neutral hydrogen (NHI) and the integrated optical depth.  Which of the following factors does *not* directly influence the calculation of NHI?
choices: The spin temperature of the gas (Tspin)
The covering factor of the background source (f)
The observed optical depth as a function of velocity (Ï„obs(v))
The redshift of the host galaxy (z)
